summary: J. D. Lavery is identified as the recipient of multiple memoranda concerning the classification of a document referred to as EX 3600. These memoranda, all dated April 7, 1977, originate from P. Haefner (or J. Haffner in one instance) and are routed via A. Addona. The documents explain and justify the classification of EX 3600 due to its connection to Operation MHCHAOS, the inclusion of information from sensitive sources and methods, and the incorporation of classified FBI reports. Lavery's role appears to be one of review or approval within the Office of General Counsel (OGC) regarding the classification status of sensitive documents.
significance: J. D. Lavery's significance in the JFK context, based on these documents, lies in their role in handling and reviewing the classification of documents related to Operation MHCHAOS, a controversial CIA operation. The documents suggest Lavery was involved in decisions regarding the accessibility and potential declassification of information related to this operation, which may have tangential connections to the JFK assassination depending on the content of EX 3600 and the broader scope of MHCHAOS.
